commentBody: Well that was delightful!

My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Water wheel?  (4)
2. Silent marching band position  (6)(4)
3. Request by those under 21  (3)(2)
4. Training facilities?  (8)(8)
5. Flight of fancy?  (7)(3)


HELM
PARADE REST
HIT ME
RAILROAD STATIONS
PRIVATE JET
Easy peasy, lemon squeezy
Fun. Easy. Great Monday! Thanks!

Nice one, C.C.!

Thanks and best wishes.

The famed pickle vendor is a really big dill.

(I relish these puns.)

In response to Sam: first, there are canned pickles although we don’t see them as often in the US—but more to the point, I think the process of making pickles from scratch is called “canning” even if they end up in jars—can any pickle aficionados confirm?

I, too, have never seen a pickle in anything other than a jar (excepting perhaps individually in a plastic bag at the gas station). Google informs me that there are indeed pickles available in metal cans. 

But the process of putting those cucumbers into glass jars, Mason or other brands, is referred to as canning. So I have no complaint with that clue.

Can fruits and vegetables in the olden days were in mason or ball glass jars in clear or blue color. 

Thus canned pickles is correct. They are canned. Not literally in a can.

A group of us, one time canned over 200 quart jars of green beans in 2 days. A produce truck heading yo the factory overturned. My dad happened to go by and the driver told anyone who stopped yo take all they wanted. So my dad and uncle shoveled 2 trunk full of green beans.

We had an assembly line going with washing, cutting, and canning green beans. Every restaurant you went to had green beans for a week. All the stores were oit of canning goods.

Yorkie-Poo? I thought that was something a sly dog named Fido might leave as a little present outside your bedroom door. Like others, I felt a can of dill pickles was quite jarring. I like the trio of leak, drip & seal (Plug it!), the trio of blip, sonar & signal (and one can throw in Roger and radio for a quintet), and there are groups, too, but I'm too lazy to list 'em. If you haven't read it, I recommend Benet's "By the Waters of Babylon," a post-apocalyptic tale that came out in 1937, and prefigures many science fiction stories published in the wake of the atomic bomb. First paragraph: The north and the west and the south are good hunting ground, but it is forbidden to go east. It is forbidden to go to any of the Dead Places except to search for metal and then he who touches the metal must be a priest or the son of a priest. Afterwards, both the man and the metal must be purified. These are the rules and the laws; they are well made. It is forbidden to cross the great river and look upon the place that was the Place of the Gods—this is most strictly forbidden. We do not even say its name though we know its name. It is there that spirits live, and demons—it is there that there are the ashes of the Great Burning. These things are forbidden—they have been forbidden since the beginning of time. *** The rest can be found here: https://www.btboces.org/Downloads/13_By%20the%20Waters%20of%20Babylon%20by%20Stephen%20Vincent%20Benet.pdf

Leave it to CC to give us a perfect Monday puzzle! The only thing is, my solve wasn't a quiet one. It was more like bam!-bam!-boom! (and finished too soon.) I had wonderful fun with it. Thank you! (ROGER took me straight to Pink Floyd. Though these days I'm not a fan of his specifically, the band's albums continue to be top-notch... https://youtu.be/84Tq-eAJIk4?si=Z7uyDzbv5MUhWuJY)
It took me way too long to realize that the RDA for the One-a-Day gummies is actually two gummies per day. So yes, one is supposed to take two gummies each day that are named “One-a-Day”.

Agree with others that when preserving food in jars, you “Can it!”

I was worried that answer was going to be sauerkraut. If someone approaches me and offers me a helping of their homemade sauerkraut, my response is: “Can it!”

Anything over 5 minutes on a Monday means I struggled. This came in right at 5:17.

Fun fact about 64A. For my 30th birthday, I did a two week two to what I call "American Oceania." Hawaii, Guam, Northern Mariana, and American Samoa.

The last one not to be confused with the independent nation of Samoa. Locally, the jurisdictions were referred to by their capitals to avoid confusion (or perhaps for anti-Imperialism reasons), Pago Pago and APIA.

Even more interestingly, the flights from Pago Pago back to Honolulu were once every three days, so it was the longest leg of my trip. I seriously considered spending one of those three days in APIA, but being on the opposite side of the international dateline from Pago Pago, I was worried I would mix the dates up and miss my flight back to Honolulu and put paid to my plans to wake up at Hawaii Volcanoes National Park on the day I turned 30.

A lot of cultural unknowns made this quite a tricky Monday for me, but I got there on the crosses.

Today's crossword adjacent trivia:
The old kingdom of Samoa used to be on the Asian side of the International Date Line, until persuaded to shift its calendar to the American side in 1892, by having two July 4th in succession.
In 1899, the Kingdom was divided between the colonial powers of Germany and the USA.
After the First World War, German Samoa became a dependency of New Zealand, then independent as Western Samoa in 1962, then just plain Samoa in 1997. And in 2011, that Samoa (half of the original Samoa) shifted back across to the Asian side of the Date Line by going straight from 29 December to 31 December.

All, that is, except for the Samoa & Tokelau Seventh Day Adventist church, who (mainly) stuck to the seven-day succession of weekdays, and so ended up celebrating their Saturday sabbath on the same day as other denominations were celebrating their Sunday sabbath.

(Some Adventist congregations did make the calendar switch, however, and it's been a source of tension in the community.)

I wasn't sure I was going to make it through the Sunday puzzle today, let alone getting around to the Monday one. My 90-year-old mother-in-law arrived today and we are preparing to take her down to the Bay Islands of Honduras on Wednesday, where she and my husband and his siblings are from. She has advanced dementia, so it complicates this kind of trip but it's the only place in her heart and mind, even if the details get jumbled up a bit these days. I'll refrain from commenting about this further than to say what a blessing it is to have people from all over the world come to this country and add to it. Of course, I'm partial to my husband as the main blessing but I do mean it across the board. 

Anywho, the puzzle! First, I just want to say that I really enjoyed Sunday's. I think it would have been more fun if I could have done it in one sitting like I normally do, but I did it in fits and spurts and then finished up tonight. I really enjoyed it the super cute theme. Some of them were quite funny! I also learned a new word, ONER.  It was the last square to complete and I was amazed that it was correct. 

Now for Monday's puzzle, fast, fun, chipper --just like Monday should be!  I know AC shows up a lot in the puzzle, but particularly apt these days. It's literally hotter here in Minnesota then it will likely be where we are in Honduras in a few days. Crazy!!

Cheers!
11 Across, cluing is weird. It’s a music *player*, not a provider.  “Provider” would typically imply a service eg Spotify.

I got the dreaded "So close" popup as I filled in my last square - the L at the crossing of GE_T and LI_. Obviously that letter was correct so I had to look elsewhere for the error.

It turned out you Americans do things differently than we do. Over here we generally report phone scams to the Office for Electronic Communications, our equivalent of your FCC, so that was what I entered. I haven't seen any bra or purse with ScRAP parts, but since "scrap" is a legitimate word rather than gibberish, it took me some time to spot the error.

It was an OK puzzle.

Btw, I started filling the grid yesterday - the fill seemed Tuesday level, so things went smoothly - but once I realized the theme was about wedding puns, I abandoned the solve. Puns annoy me, and I can't stand weddings. The grandest one I ever went to was of the most miserably mismatched couple I know - like they thought throwing money at the party would change things between them. Well, it didn't. Fourteen years later they are obviously unhappy. The only time I see them smile is looking at their staged wedding photo.

My wife and I got married at city hall, with just the official and two witnesses there, and then we had a laid back party for our closest 15 people at our favorite restaurant. That was so much more *us* than a grand wedding! Secular, private, almost intimate, and completely against tradition. As you can guess, we didn't hire a photographer to pose us against some random backdrop for perfect photos, either 🤣
“In app,” two days in a row?
Finished in 8:56, cut my average almost exactly in half(8:55 faster)! Been really fun to see how much I've improved in 64 days of daily xwords ^v^

Where's the Constructor comments? Also, there is an old-fashioned custom of "canning" that involved preserving foods in jars. I gather that's what the "can" refers to. Nice puzzle. Would love to see more of these.

It's always nice to see a puzzle from CC. This was a quick one for me.

Thanks, CC.
Pretty nice theme, and really fun fill. I never felt I was getting bored while solving. I think this one of the best Mondays we've had in a while
Always good to see Zhouqin's name as we know we are in for a treat.

Fun Monday puzzle (all in the clues)  from one of my favorite constructors. None of the theme answers were going to come to me just from the clues, but they all came smoothly with just some down crosses. That added to the enjoyment - and... I still came in right at my Monday average. 

And... a quite unusual puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

..

Funday, Monday!

Thanks CC,

Sincerely,
CC

Zippy Monday! Cute theme. I thought it was interesting that all of the theme answers  included double letters (DILL, SLEEPING, BEDROOM DOOR, and DRESS). DRESS SHIRT had a triple S. Since there wasn’t a revealer, I pondered whether the double letters signified something? They sort of spell Leos 🤔 I found another mini theme SONAR, BLIP, SIGNAL, ROGER, RADIO, and maybe including SPY and LEAK. I also liked ALOHA crossing APIA and RAH crossing HAD A BLAST. I’m always impressed by the constructors who have “hit the cycle”. Thank you for starting off the week with a fun grid, CC!
Because Monday puzzles are of course usually easy I try to fill in all the blanks just using the across clues. Sometimes I can, sometimes I can’t. Today I could.

Strands #477
“Breaking up the band”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵

Clever one today. No spoilers above the fold 😉

It's a pleasure to see a Monday puzzle by a seasoned constructor. Everyone is saying it (or not): https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=r3kQlzOi27M&pp=ygUfb3VyIGxpcHMgYXJlIHNlYWxlZCB0aGUgZ28tZ28ncw%3D%3D CC, you go-go, girl!

Nice simple Monday theme. 

A little surprised to see APIA in a Monday grid, especially since it could have been edited away almost effortlessly. I wonder if it was left since LIPS---Button them!---resonates in a way with the puzzle's theme?

Then again, I suppose folks need to learn (or review) APIA, and today's appearance of the place name was an especially benign one.

But...but...where was the VELCRO?  (As in, "One, two; velcro my shoe.")

I have a guild meeting to get to, so in a burst of excess efficiency, I've already put the puzzle in the recycling bin--both sdes having been used.  If I had thought of something more to say, it's gone now...  Oh--ZIP your LIP?

CC always delivers a solid and enjoyable puzzle.  Thank you!!
I used to work at a pickle factory. Until I got canned.
ASANA? Never heard of it.

Nice one CeCe.

TORSO is making the rounds these days along with ODOR.  I guess they are related.

Off to Maine this week after several delays (cue rants about auto repair and shipping).  We will return to MS in late October missing some of the hurricane season.

Smooth Monday solve, thanks again.

Good morning! Had mini before NANO, SLYfox before DOG.
KOLA nuts always remind me of the (old) 7up commercial about the "uncola". 
I'm sentimental. I still miss the old AOL platform. Made a lot of (still) good friends in the Trivia chatroom back in the 90s. None of the current apps enable quite that kind of casual conversational flow. And I'm still attached to my old screenname.

I'm SCOLDing myself because I had FCC instead of FTC.  Phones are communication after all (and SONAR, SIGNAL and RADIO probably help solidify that frame of mind).  It made SCRAP which is clearly wrong in retrospect, but since it is a word, my mind kept on skipping over it when I was looking for errors.  Worst Monday time since OLDEN days.

Still a fun puzzle.  Thanks for letting me vent.  Now I'll make like a SLEEPING BAG and zip it.
beat my monday record today! 5:43

Fun puzzle. But I would think that dill pickles are canned, an end product of the process. 

What are canned are cucumbers, which become pickles. 

My buba’s garden, Clearfield County, PA. Tall, fragrant stalks of dill, grown next to garlic and onions. Pickling day was a big affair and with hot stuff I had to keep out of the way. Not so with pie day. My dad, uncles, and I brought back buckets of blackberries. Buba let me help wash them and fill the pies. Then she would roll out the leftover pie dough, slice it, sprinkle it with cinnamon and sugar, and bake. A treat just for me.

That felt a little crunchy for a Monday, but no less enjoyable. Lots of unknown names, offset by a few gimmes.
It took me a while to work out the theme, DILL PICKLE didn’t help. I’ve never seen a can of the above, only in jars. 
The penny didn’t drop til I got to DRESS SHIRT. Doh.

We’ve seen “___ it!” clues before, such as [Darn it!] for SOCKS and [Beat it!] for EGG, but I don’t believe that they’ve ever been turned into a theme, as Zhouqin (aka CC) did today.  That is a stellar crossword mind at work.  Nailed it!

Fun theme, too, with trying to guess the theme answers with as few crosses as possible.

Plus, the grid today is awash in lovely serendipities:
•	The rhyming BLIP and DRIP.  Saying them over and over sounds like windshield wipers.
•	A SIDE touching a side.
•	Crossing echoes: IN APP (which appeared yesterday), and CRIB (as in Saturday’s “Crib for a doll” for BARBIE DREAMHOUSE).
•	Double-O gathering with SPOON crossing BEDROOM DOOR.
•	Rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap: STRAP.
•	DOG crossing POO (Hi, @John Ezra), and also, re dog: FIDO and STAY.

A touch of brilliance, fun, and little treasures brought sweetness to the box today.  Brightened my day right up – thank you, CC!

Down only clues and solved with no problem. For any 10-minute Saturday solvers (?!?) out there, Mondays down only is always a fun challenge!

One of my favorite - albeit lowbrow - pieces of literary-inspired music is Kama Sutra by surf rock band the Swamis. Fun album if you're a fan of surf beat.
YouTube never heard of them apparently or I'd post the track but their cd is for sale on ebay

We’ve seen “___ it!” clues before, such as [Darn it!] for SOCKS and [Beat it!] for EGG, but I don’t believe that they’ve ever been turned into a theme, as Zhouqin (aka CC) did today. That is a stellar crossword mind at work. Nailed it!

Plus, some lovely serendipities: A SIDE touching a side, a rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap, and the rhyming BLIP and DRIP (saying those two words over and over sounds like windshield wipers).  

A touch of brilliance, fun, and little treasures brought sweetness to the box today. Brightened my day right up – thank you, CC!

Very enjoyable, a nice relaxing Monday.

Well, it was relaxing once I realized I wasn't being constantly told to be quiet.
Paraphrasing from today’s Gameplay newsletter by Elie Levine: Starting June 30, there will be a new forum called Strands Sidekick.
My ear memory messed me up with "Stephen Vincent ___," and I had no idea how to fix PRTIAMS at 37D. "Spin doctor" means nothing to me anymore/so far.

Fun puzzle. 

And it was a nice drill for remembering how to interpret the imperative when it's not in quotes.

That has taken me a while.
Easy. Seen several of these words recently.
The exclamation point punctuated clues are annoying and childish, and now we get a puzzle full of them. Great.

It didn't get as much news coverage as the sourdough baking, but there was a definite spike in home canning during the Covid lockdowns. We were going through pallets of Mason-type glass jars at my A to Z warehouse every night. And that's a good thing.

Shout-out to Captain Quahog: You're in today's Brendan Emmett Quigley puzzle! https://www.brendanemmettquigley.com (After you do the puzzle, you can read my Diary of a Crossword Fiend review.) https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/06/22/monday-june-23-2025/

[… it!] clues are probably my least favorite clues unless the answer is unique or clever in some way.  Luckily my mild sense of annoyance at those clues in general and the notion of canned DILLPICKLES in particular passed as quickly as did the puzzle.

Ms Burnikel is awesome.  Her friends call her CC.  She is a master at crossword design.  I always love solving her puzzles. I did not know she "hit for the cycle" but it does not surprise me. Well done CC.
Hi, Sam! Pickles are canned!
So fun and fresh clueing for a Monday. Thank you!
who in god's name is Lil Tecca
pickles are bottled in glass sometimes sold in plastic..  hello so you can reseal the lid and this is a NYC puzzle... wow

you can tomatoes and other things you preserve pickles in a jar

preserve is the verb hello
@Lewis YAY! I was too late to make the comment, but I specifically wanted to ask you if either 4 or 5 was a new enough clue to make your list--I thought they were great, and so close to one another.

Steve,

This is not the first time you have posted this comment about a Monday puzzle. You do understand Monday puzzles are supposed to be the easiest?
@Barry Ancona https://youtu.be/2AB9zPfXqQQ?si=wGJ_LGbsQPCYLpAZ

@Barry Ancona
And just what is the point of calling out a perfectly light hearted comment?

@Hanson
Right!  So I went back and Clicked a Recommedation.

Mike,

I'll ketchup with you later.

@Mike

He started bottling them at home and is making a fortune. Now he lives in a condo mint.

@Mike
Folks are beginning to sour on those posts....

@Mike

for brine out loud . . .

@Mike
These puns are really becoming your bread and butter.  You're getting a real cornichon the market.
@SP yes it is
@SP I blame today's pickle discourse for the impromptu canning-in-a-jar I did this afternoon. On Thursday, I hope to have the half-sours to show for it.

@Kevin

Looks like you and I cross posted (see below)—thanks for confirming

@Kevin I think the challenge is the verb “to can”.  Canning…preserving of fruit and vegetables by people who du such things is often done in jars.  

So yes, the end product is in a mason jar but you canned the pickles.
Kevin and SP, I thought Sam was word-playing. I'm guessing she is aware that "canning" is about preserving food in any sealed container. https://nchfp.uga.edu/how/can
@The X-Phile AH! "Canisters" makes sense to me, and I see how we got here.

@john ezra Thanks for the Benet tip - it'll be my next read. Years ago, I came upon a worn volume of "John Brown's Body" on one of my dad's (many) bookshelves, and was for some reason intrigued. Once I started it, I couldn't put it down. Recently, I tried to track down a copy for myself, only to discover that it wasn't stocked by one of the largest U.S. bookseller chains. After scolding a company representative over the phone, I finally tracked it down elsewhere, but I have often thought that it is a sadly overlooked classic. It is a beautifully written, and thoroughly American, epic poem, and deserves more recognition than it gets.

@sotto voce

Who is this CC you and Barry both mention?

Bill,

C.C. is the constructor. She offered that years ago as an easy way to come close to pronouncing her first name.

@Barry Ancona

Interesting. My attempt to say Zhouqin would sound nothing like C.C.

@sotto voce Hey, Sotto. In case you haven’t seen it, this is my favorite video of David Gilmour playing Wish You Were Here (live unplugged, sorta). Bonus: no R. Waters. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=3j8mr-gcgoI&pp=0gcJCf0Ao7VqN5tD The song is timeless. First one I played on the acoustic my family gave me for Christmas. In fact, you inspired me to start my day playing it right now!

@The X-Phile. I’ve heard the same thing from students who used English first names—that our well-meaning mispronunciation of Chinese, which also includes the tones, changed their name to a completely different word.

@ The X-Phile

Indeed, many of my Chinese students have chosen American names, but some have not. In the latter case, I simply do my best and hope no one giggles or gasps.

In any case, I'd try something like "Zhoh-chin(g)" for Zhouqin, so "C.C." still puzzles me.

@Warren

Yes, yes, yes to David Gilmour! 

I didn't know this unplugged version, so thank you for that. 

(I was tempted to link to him minus ROGER, but had to unfortunately stay true to the puzzle entry...)

@sotto voce

Yeah, I figured…otherwise we’d spend all day swapping videos with no relation to the puzzle.

@Warren

And wouldn't that be fun! :-)

@sotto voce She gives a fuller explanation for her name in the constructor notes for this Wordplay article: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/22/crosswords/figure-skating-event.html Times style is a stickler for Mandarin transliteration, it would seem.

@DQ

They should be compelled to change their name due to "false advertising".  ;-)

@Cat Lady Margaret

I'm sure you'll all be fascinated by this piece of personal trivial from a trivial person:

Of all the foods that are repulsive to me, sauerkraut is light-years ahead of second place.  I absolutely cannot stand the sight, smell, or sound of it.  (Oh, it has a sound--I can hear the sound.)

Just thinking about it is causing my stomach to get queasy.  And I have a very strong stomach.  I once went 38 years between.

@Andrzej 
I am a descendant of Mainers, and I can tell you that the traditional cuisine is very bland. Fortunately, I also have German/Polish forebears. My grandparents made big crocks of sauerkraut every summer to last until spring. My favorite dish with kraut is choucroute.
@Francis  -  Sauerkraut mellows considerably if you bake it 20-30 minutes.  With short ribs or even just hot dogs in a baking pan.

@Mark

I'm guessing you mean choucroute garnie.  Because choucroute itself is French for sauerkraut.

@Francis

I don't feel repulsed by sauerkraut as you do, but it's been years since I've put it on a hot dog or anything else.  It doesn't do anything for me at all, at least in a culinary sense.  I'll leave the digestive information to Andrzej.

@Steve L 
Often just called choucroute here in the USA.

@Francis
Wow.
We are fine with that; leaves more for us--we who know a good food when we taste it.
(Maybe someone served you substandard sauerkraut?  A terrible disservice!)

My hate list is fairly short: turnip greens, turnips, Earl Grey tea, runny Brie, (and "sweet tea" which became  'a thing' in my long absence....whilst I was living amongst the Yankees.)
@Mark And in France as well. My French family called a choucroute garnie just a choucroute.

@Tom
Aha! Thanks for weighing in!

@Mean Old Lady 
That is a short list! Turnips have to be young and straight out of the ground in order to be edible. I don't hate the earl's tea, but it is far from my favorite. My hate list mostly comprises rotten cheese, any that "ripens" or has mold in it, yuck.
@Andrzej Eww, I'm part Polish and part Ukrainian (along with part Sicilian). I love pierogi, but mushrooms in them make me want to vomit. I don't ever do fungus. It's disgusting.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight

Good.  More left for me...

@Andrzej

I love both sauerkraut and kimchi. We get a locally-made miso kimchi here that would rock your world.

@Oikofuge

Every time I hear about a massive time shift (24 hours is pretty massive) I wonder if people who are paying or receiving rent are able to come to terms with what should or should not be paid for "extra" days or "missing" days.
@Andrzej Yes, we do rent each month the same. We have leases that specify what that will be.

@Francis My previous response has been emued, probably because I wrote that a group of people were *not*[something insulting] as commonly assumed. It'll show up tomorrow, probably. My point was that exactly what you worry about actually happened during the Julian-Gregorian calendar shift. In the UK there were "give us back our eleven days" protests, not from people who imagined they'd been robbed of lifespan, as is commonly suggested, but because they were paid daily, but owed fixed rent monthly. I wrote more last time, but the story is here: https://oikofuge.com/old-lady-day/

@Francis Which of course happened in the UK when the calendar shifted from Julian to Gregorian. The "give us back our eleven days" protests weren't from stupid people who thought their lives had been shortened, but people who were paid daily but had rent due monthly. Our tax year in the UK ends on April 5, and that's in part because the government had to shift it from the start of the year, which in those days began on the spring quarter-day, March 25. https://oikofuge.com/old-lady-day/

@Oikofuge

... and it appears!

@Oikofuge

Thanks!

I thought I had remembered hearing that about the 11 day calendar shift.  

But I think I was only in the first or second grade when I heard it, so I couldn't really trust my memory.

It is kind of a weird psychological issue.  We're so tied to a calendar, to have it changed seems like a time-space warp.

@RozzieGrandma

Yeah, I am definitely not without a lot of extra concern this year 😬

@Beth in Greenbelt

Lizard! Oh my goodness, she never thought of that one!! I am glad you saw that comment though, I was hoping you would! 

I hope your visit with your mother-in-law goes well!  I hope she will be able to adjust and find a good community in her new situation.  It's all so hard! 

My mother-in-law is now a little beyond knowing what she's lost, which is both fortunate in a way for her and unfortunate.... It was very scary for her to realize that she was slipping.  Now, she doesn't seem to realize it and she's actually happier. So hard!

@Scott G

Right? I was very confused by the clue. Weird wordingx especially on Monday.
@Scott G I think you're being a little too literal. The Nano provided (as in supplied, gave, spewed, etc.) music, so it's not unfair to say it's a music provider.

@Ethan

It didn't occur to me as I was solving, but I'd have to side with Scott and Andrzej here. Devices like iPods are storage devices only; they only "supply" what you have already stocked them with.  They don't contain anything to give you on their own.  On the other hand, if the clue was about an iPhone, I might be persuaded differently.

@Andrzej

We loved our wedding day but unlike so many, I'll never call it the best day of my life. It was beautiful and fun and happy, but everyday since I met him has increasingly been the best day of my life. Even though the shi%tiest of circumstances.

We were very budget conscious and did a bunch of stuff ourselves and or friends offered to use there particular talents as their gift to us, such as my friend who did all the flowers as her gift and similar things. 

So many people said to us on the wedding day and later and even years later that they thought it was the best wedding they've ever been to and that it truly felt like... Like it embodied both of us, that the wedding itself reflected who we are separately on as a couple. That was the best compliment I could have received. 

But I also don't disagree with you about a lot of very fancy weddings that have been to that seemed to be more about the wedding than the person. So I totally get your feelings about weddings.

@HeathieJ

"... it embodied both of us, that the wedding itself reflected who we are separately on as a couple."

That speaks to me! Our "wedding" felt the same - we did it how we wanted.

BTW, ever practical and rational, we got married for legal reasons - I had inherited some money and property, while she earned more than me, and we were about to buy a property of our own - we wanted there to be no doubt what would happen with all that we owned when one of us died, say. We could have sorted all that out with contracts, but getting married seemed less complicated than that.

Does that sound pragmatic and not at all romantic? It should, because neither of us believes in rituals, so emotionally marriage meant little to us. We had already been living together for years, trusting and respecting one another. We needed no antiquated rite to strengthen our bond. We also almost never do something because "that's what you are supposed to do."

Don't get me wrong - my wife is the best person I have ever met and I love how she completes me and gives everything meaning - but what we have and what we feel is in no way dependant upon marriage. The day we got married was not "the most important day of my life" - that would be the day I met my partner, because she really has changed me myself and my life, making it something I would never have imagined before.

All that being said, I'm sad and angry same sex couples can't get married over here. It's so inhumanely cruel and discriminatory!
@Andrzej    Legal marriage was invented to deal with property rights, and your wedding ceremony is a modern example.  It does eliminate estate paperwork between the couple.
@Andrzej Your situation mirrors the situation of me and my (now) husband. Got married for legal reasons at the Justice of the Peace office and my "new husband" went back to work.

@Andrzej

“I'm sad and angry same sex couples can't get married over here.”

Thanks. My husband and I have been together since 1978, but didn’t get married until 2014, after federal recognition of same-sex marriages became the law. (It would be another 10 months before the US Supreme Court forced states like Texas, where we lived then, to recognize our marriage.)

As it happened, only a few months after we were married, I had emergency cardiac surgery. I don’t know if we would have had any trouble with my husband being able to see me in the hospital and participate in my health care decisions if we hadn’t been married, but it was nice not to have to worry about that. And it saved us a lot of money for a few years when I could put him on my health insurance, a job benefit I’d been denied for a long time. 

(We had a very nice wedding, not too big. We rented the entire inn (six or seven rooms) for three nights and got to spend a lot of time with our families and close friends.)

@Andrzej

We have a saying in English, "It's not the wedding, it's the marriage."  Selfish brides who wreak havoc because "it's my special day" are selfish people in the first place.  Selfish relatives who want things their way are even worse.  Most of the time, the groom (if there is one, of course; that's not guaranteed these days) is usually not heavily invested in the details.  

Marriage can be based on romantic ideals, but at heart (pardon the pun), people in long-term cohabitating relationships should get married for legal protections, if for no other reasons.  The right to your spouse's pension, social security, assets, property, etc., and the right to be legally in charge in a medical emergency cannot be overstressed.

That said, our wedding was a moderately expensive affair 46 years ago, but not too lavish--typical, I guess, for the place and time.  My mother-in-law, who was just getting back on her feet after recovering financially from her own divorce, was happy to foot the bill.

But more importantly, my bride and I had established a relationship over several years that seemed solid enough to take the next step.  And the marriage has endured through nearly half a century as a result.

We're not perfect, but we make it work.  Some spouses finish the other's sentences; I finish her leftovers.  It works for us.

Your husband is one very lucky guy.  I am happy for you. 🙂

@Lars

At risk of making a very bad pun, I think you're missing the point.

The exclamation points are not just decorative.  Neither are they "annoying and childish"; that's just how you feel about them, perhaps because you don't understand why they're there.

These clues are a unique category.  Any clue that ends in [...it!] (without quotation marks) is a self-referential one.  For example, the clue [Darn it!] refers to the answer TEAR (5/15/25), SOCK (9/15/23) or HOLE (8/10/17), because tears, socks or holes are what you darn.  [Believe it!] once clued TENET (2/9/25).  [Stuff it!] once led to PEPPER (10/11/23).  [Make a run for it!] clued SEAT (4/5/25).

When there are quotation marks, the clue works like most normal clues; ["Darn it!"] has led to OH POOH, RATS, AW NUTS, and several other equivalents.

Instead of griping about a perceived problem, you can up your game by understanding how the game works.

@Bill, I'm a chef, with a respected diploma, and I know nothing about getting sick from "improperly" cooked beans. Will you explain please? To cook dried beans you can soak them overnight, or do a quick soak by bringing tom to a brisk boil for 5 minutes, then cutting the heat, and covering the pan for an hour. Then you can add goodies like onions and spices, and simmer until done. There is no place in this process that anything bad should happen. 🤷🏼‍♀️

@Bill, thanks for the link. That's a very specific and unusual case, but good to know nonetheless. 

We stocked up on various flours and dry legumes at a co-op in NH, but we've always been cooks and bakers, so we did use and enjoy those things. But I don't question what others did or didn't do with their purchases. I assume most who bought raw ingredients knew what to do with them.

@Bill, the only reason we have high risk of salmonella from eggs is our filthy and barbaric food supply chain. In Europe, eggs aren't even refrigerated in grocery stores because they don't need to have chicken poop washed off them, leaving the natural protection on the shell. Here, eggs are dirty when chickens are raised in batteries of stacked cages and defecating all over all the chickens below them. Eggs from true free range chickens are clean. Furthermore, duck eggs are not a risk either; ducks cannot survive in their own filth, so they are always free to roam.

@Bill

@Susan E
Completely agree with you about the eggs. The same would hold true for many foods, especially chicken and ground meats. And don't trust that "hydroponic, pre-washed" baby spinach!

Since the last round of Avian flu, and the ensuing "egg shortage," the producers have had to "ramp up production at the egg factories"--by which I mean our sentient dinosaurette friends! As a result I've noticed a marked decrease in the quality of the eggs--yolks which break before they touch the pan, thin whites which won't whip. 

But few institutions, and indeed few homemakers, can afford the economic luxury of "free-range" or "organic," at least in this country. (FWIW, all eggs sold in Mich. must be certified "cage-free," which, as you know, is not the same thing.) I once got into a heated dispute on this forum over this, stemming from my suggestion to add gelatin to lemon curd as a thickener.

Of course, all this is the rationale for espousing veganism, which neither Temple Grandin nor I do.

"I assume most who bought raw ingredients knew what to do with them." You have more faith in the culinary intelligence of the average shopper than I.
